text: <@U13TWBRBL> and <@U2X9KDDL7>: Thanks I will use your compose today - I attempted the same with <@U0ULK2JPP> yesterday but for some reason our addition did not resolve the problem ( we still saw the orderer errors on startup)

<@U0ULK2JPP> <@U0KQ9QKH6> I've completed a docker-compose.yml which runs membersrvc, orderer, vp0, and creates a docker image in which to run the unit tests.  I had to modify the unit tests slightly so that you can specify various service addresses and ports via environment variable (which has precedent already in various programs, so it's nothing really new).  I'm only getting one unit test failure -- the second test of endorser-tests.js
I'd like to send the files along to you.  Let me know if/when you'd like them.  (I don't have git access, and wouldn't have time today to set that up)
<@U2X9KDDL7>  You could post the docker-compose.yml and unit test diff here as a start
<@U0KQ9QKH6> Ok -- I'm going to pull and make sure it's working on the latest.  Quick question: The endorser is a peer, right?  And should have the same address/port as the peer?
I'm getting another error -- this one in end-to-end.js.  I'll post the files now though.

<@U2X9KDDL7|vdods> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/vdods/F2XMXJ7KR/docker-compose.yml|docker-compose.yml for running unit tests + services> and commented: I made a few changes to the unit test js files -- the various addresses and ports of services are specified using environment variables.  I'll attach those files next.

file.name: docker-compose.yml
file.title: docker-compose.yml for running unit tests + services
file.preview:
version: '2'
services:
    membersrvc:
        image: hyperledger/fabric-membersrvc
        command: membersrvc
file.preview_highlight:
version: '2'
services:
    membersrvc:
        image: hyperledger/fabric-membersrvc
        command: membersrvc

initial_comment.comment: I made a few changes to the unit test js files -- the various addresses and ports of services are specified using environment variables.  I'll attach those files next.

text: <@U2X9KDDL7> endorser is a Peer and the SDK uses the Peer.js class under the cover to represent the endorser endpoint and grpc client for it
<@U2X9KDDL7|vdods> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/vdods/F2XMG9LBW/test-env.dockerfile|test-env.Dockerfile>

file.name: test-env.Dockerfile
file.title: test-env.Dockerfile
file.preview:
# Start with an image that has most of the necessary tools
FROM hyperledger/fabric-src:x86_64-0.7.0-snapshot-898ea6e
ENV FABRIC_SDK_NODE_DIR $GOPATH/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-node/
# In order for `npm install` to complete successfully, node-gyp requires python 2, so install it and set the PYTHON env var.
RUN apt-get update && \
file.preview_highlight:

text: hey <@U1W210996> - did you ever figure out `transport: http2Server.HandleStreams failed to receive the preface from client: EOF` error?
<@U0KQ9QKH6> I just put docker-compose.yml and test-env.Dockerfile in the root directory of fabric-sdk-node, but it could go somewhere else.
or does anyone know why or how to avoid this error? causing `hfc` transaction to never successfully send back completion
<@U1W210996|zemtsov> has joined the channel
<@U2WAP0R6J> Yes. It is reporting every time. I don’t know what it means but is doesn’t break my work. I left it for now
<@U1W210996> hmm, i never get a completed event back from hfc on deploy or invoke and i'm guessing this is why
despite the fact that the chaincode state is succesfully updated
i'm running fedora 23 - can I ask what you're running to get this error?
<@U13TWBRBL> <@U11HH3P7Y> please see <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1727/>
it may result in building tests twice - however, I think that running tests should be baked into gulp rather than separate
<@U2WAP0R6J> you mean my os?
yeah
<@U2WAP0R6J> I start images and nodejs application from MacOS
hmm ok
<@U0KM61BCP>: all executors are busy in process and you are jobs are in queue. <https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/job/fabric-sdk-node-verify-x86_64/>

<@U2WAP0R6J> this is example from my log:
```vp0_1         | 15:46:34.501 [consensus/pbft] execDoneSync -> INFO 06e Replica 0 finished execution 13, trying next
vp1_1         | 15:46:36.190 [consensus/pbft] execDoneSync -> INFO 055 Replica 1 finished execution 13, trying next
vp2_1         | 15:46:36.845 [consensus/pbft] execDoneSync -> INFO 055 Replica 2 finished execution 13, trying next
vp3_1         | 15:46:36.930 [consensus/pbft] execDoneSync -> INFO 056 Replica 3 finished execution 13, trying next
vp0_1         | 2016/11/02 15:46:46 transport: http2Server.HandleStreams failed to receive the preface from client: EOF
vp0_1         | 2016/11/02 15:46:46 transport: http2Server.HandleStreams failed to receive the preface from client: EOF```

And the code deploys and invokes successfully

<@U2WAP0R6J> <@U1W210996> I'm curious if either of you could show me some example node.js code for sendTransaction, including handling the completion/failure event.  The fabric-sdk-node docs are a little slim on that method.
<@U2XM0F3BN|nagatrip> has joined the channel
<@U1W210996|zemtsov> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/zemtsov/F2XNFS3S9/-.js|Untitled> and commented: <@U2WAP0R6J> This is a short example

file.name: -.js
file.title: Untitled
file.preview_highlight:
var deployRequest = {
    chaincodePath: ccPath,
    fcn: "init",
    args: []
  }

text: `deployer` is a user which should be enrolled
look at this example: <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/v0.6/sdk/node/test/unit/asset-mgmt-with-roles.js>
<@U1W210996> Hmm.. the methods used in that example seem to be deprecated (they're not present in the current state of hyperledger/fabric-sdk-node
Though maybe I'm supposed to be using sdk node from v0.6 branch on fabric repo
<@U2X9KDDL7> Ohh. Quick changes

<@U0KM61BCP> I agree that test should be run from a gulp command, at the minimum “gulp test” to run the whole suite (which would require prep/teardown with the target network) and “gulp test-headless” for just the headless tests (for quick check)
<@U1C3LNJ58> has been working in this area and I know he’s using a similar library to launch test suites from files but it’s not gulp-npm-test
I’ve asked him to prepare for an initial changeset to be put up for review, but he’s been delayed due to v0.6 testing
Well that's fine I guess. UT should not require any setup/tear down ... a dev should be able to put a watch on and tests should run automagically

"a dev should be able to put a watch on and tests should run automagically” - I have to say I’m a little skeptical of that aspect of the gulp-npm-test lib, I personally wouldn’t set it up like that because my code won’t be ready until I know it’s ready, and I’d launch a comprehensive test to make sure. trying to run unit tests on file save feels way too aggressive and unnecessary. but if you or others have done this and have good feedback, I’m all ears
<@U0KM61BCP> btw I agree that the gulp test should allow for a switch to tell it not to bother with setting up and tearing down the target network, would be useful when ran by developers locally
<@U2X9KDDL7> note that endorser-tests.js and end-to-end.js both depend on <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2155/> to be merged to run successfully against the latest fabric
Ah, gotcha.  Fortunately, the docker-compose environment should be independent of that change.
The documentation on Member.sendTransaction is still missing -- is there any information on what the format of its parameter(s) is/are?
Also, is there a reason that the fabric-sdk-node/package.json version is 0.0.2 instead of something like 0.6.x?

<@U2X9KDDL7> we need to beef up the sendTransaction() jsdoc, in the meanwhile the test end-to-end.js has sample snippet:

				var tx = new _fabricProto.Transaction2();
				tx.setEndorsedActions([{
					actionBytes: response.actionBytes,
					endorsements: response.response.endorsement
				}]);

				return webUser.sendTransaction(tx.toBuffer());
we’ll update the version to 1.0.0 when we start publishing it to npm, right now just an internal random number less than 1.0

<@U2X9KDDL7> you are welcome to submit a changeset for your environment variables support for the tests. one suggestion is that instead of parsing env variables directly, use the hierarchical configuration mechanism that <@U1KFBBWG1> wrote, that way we have more flexibility in managing the config values (like using files as default for “local” vs. “CI” environments, and use env var to override all)
<@U13TWBRBL> I've got a Linux Foundation ID, and I can see the Jira board -- does that mean I have push access to the Gerrit repo?  If so, I can do that.
That being said, all the docker files as well as the env-var-modified unit test files are posted in this channel (scroll up a bit)

<@U2X9KDDL7> if you are experienced with Gerrit already then it’d be a good idea for you to push a changeset. we welcome contribution from all interested parties. if this is likely a one-off contribution then it’s probably not worth the learning curve on Gerrit and coding standard etc.

<@U13TWBRBL> For now it's likely to be a one-off contribution, and I'm short on time until a week and a half from now.  Otherwise I'd be interested.  For future reference, is there a coding standards doc?
there’s a simple “contributor checklist” in the README of the project (fabric-sdk-node)
Thanks, I'll take a look and keep it in mind!
